elements.content: The reactions of bis(pyridinecarboxamido)alkanes with copper(II) in the presence of various anions and solvent systems afforded several polymeric crystalline complexes with or without guest inclusion. The crystal structure analyses of these complexes reveal that the coordination networks observed here include open one-dimensional (1D) chains containing cavities and open (4,4)-networks with three types of packing modes, namely, mixed, offset−offset, and trigonal, doubly interpenetrated (4,4)-networks both in parallel and in perpendicular (diagonal/diagonal) modes and a three-dimensional pseudo-diamondoid (658-topology) network. The self-complementary amide groups of the ligands assembled these coordination networks into higher dimensional architectures via N−H···O hydrogen bonds. The exchange of counteranions from the polymeric crystalline complexes was found to trigger the network transformations. The 1D chain, which has rectangular cavities, was transformed into a pseudo-diamondoid network upon exchange of ClO4 - with PF6 - anions. The exchange of anions from two-dimensional (2D) open (4,4)-networks resulted in 2D-interpenetrated networks. It was found that the reverse exchange that is expected to result in open networks from interpenetrated networks is not allowed. The guest molecules included in these networks range from small molecules such as H2O, EtOH, and CHCl3 to big aromatic molecules such as nitrobenzene, toluene, anisole, p-xylene, benzonitrile, and naphthalene. The exchange of guest molecules in crystal-to-crystal fashion was also found to trigger the transformations in the mode of packing of 2D layers.

elements.content: Crystal engineering involves the task of building supramolecular systems by designing rational synthetic schemes utilizing the various possible intermolecular interactions. Understanding the nature of the intermolecular interactions, which assemble the building blocks into supramolecular arrays, is important in developing methodologies for crystal syntheses. The construction of one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) using coordinate bonds has resulted in new materials with interesting properties. On the other hand, construction of similar architectures using strong hydrogen bonds has also been shown to produce functional materials with useful properties. Several recent studies have shown the utility of hydrogen-bond interactions in assembling coordination complexes into higher aggregates. However, studies using the combination of coordination bonds and hydrogen bonds in designing coordination polymers are relatively rare. Such studies should deal with the design of the ligands having a minimum of two types of functional groups; one of the two should recognize itself (self-recognition synthon), and other should propagate the network with transition metal atoms. Designing such ligands achieves the following objectives:  (a) it introduces the functional groups in to the polymeric networks; (b) these functional groups help in fine-tuning the nature of the cavities; (c) self-recognition synthons act as communicators and assembles polymeric networks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering involves the task of building supramolecular systems by designing rational synthetic schemes utilizing the various possible intermolecular interactions. Understanding the nature of the intermolecular interactions, which assemble the building blocks into supramolecular arrays, is important in developing methodologies for crystal syntheses. The construction of one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) using coordinate bonds has resulted in new materials with interesting properties. On the other hand, construction of similar architectures using strong hydrogen bonds has also been shown to produce functional materials with useful properties. Several recent studies have shown the utility of hydrogen-bond interactions in assembling coordination complexes into higher aggregates. However, studies using the combination of coordination bonds and hydrogen bonds in designing coordination polymers are relatively rare. Such studies should deal with the design of the ligands having a minimum of two types of functional groups; one of the two should recognize itself (self-recognition synthon), and other should propagate the network with transition metal atoms. Designing such ligands achieves the following objectives: (a) it introduces the functional groups in to the polymeric networks; (b) these functional groups help in fine-tuning the nature of the cavities; (c) self-recognition synthons act as communicators and assembles polymeric networks.

elements.content: The proper selection of ligands is an important aspect in obtaining the framework materials with the above-mentioned properties. Accordingly, ligands 1 and 2 are selected in this contribution for constructing coordination networks and assembling them into higher dimensional architectures via hydrogen-bonded interactions (Scheme ). These ligands contain the pyridyl groups, which are separated by amide moieties and an alkyl chain. The pyridyl groups can form coordinate bonds, while the amide groups help in assembling the networks via complementary hydrogen-bonded interactions. The amide moieties can form various types of hydrogen-bonded synthons as shown in Scheme .

elements.content: Because compounds 1 and 2 are exo bidentate ligands, they are expected to form the networks that are known for rod-type ligands. The networks obtained from rod-type bidentate ligands include 1D chain, zigzag, helical, ladder, 2D square grid, herringbone, brickwall, bilayer and 3D cubical, diamondoid, and so on. The flexibility of the alkyl chain further increases the diversity in the types of frameworks that can be formed. Recently, we have shown that the ligand 2a assembles into 2D open and interpenetrated networks with secondary building units of CuI (Cu2I2 or Cu4I4). In these structures, the formation of synthon I was observed between the 2D layers. In contrast to these results, the formation of synthon I was observed within the 2D layers when 2a is treated with Cu(SCN)2 in the presence of nitrobenzene. Further, 2a with Zn(ClO4)2 was shown by Vittal et al. to form 1D chain containing cavities, whereas ligand 1a was shown to form two types of networks, a triply interpenetrated 2D layer and 1D network containing cavities, with Cu(ClO4)2 in the same reaction flask. These results prompted us to explore the effects of anions and guest molecules in the formation of MOFs containing Cu(II) and ligands 1 or 2. The anions considered for these studies include nitrate, perchlorate, and hexaflurophosphate. The complexes of 1 or 2 with Cu(II) have been synthesized either by direct reactions which are done in the presence of various guest molecules or by exchanging anions from already formed polymeric crystalline complexes. In all these structures, the amide moieties assembled coordination networks via hydrogen bonds and the MOF geometries include 1D chains with guest inclusion, (4,4)-open 2D networks with the inclusion of guest/anions in the cavities, (4,4) 2-fold interpenetrated networks, and a doubly interpenetrated pseudo-diamondoid network. Further, we have also studied anion exchange, guest exchange, and guest absorption properties of these materials. Therefore, in this paper, we will focus our attention on the following aspects:

elements.content:
(1) The assembly of coordination networks via amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds

(2) Geometrical analysis of molecules vs synthons observed (I−III)

(3) Differences between 3-pyridyl and 4-pyridyl in coordination to Cu(II)

(4) Differences in the geometry of the ligands due to the flexibility of the alkyl spacers

(5) Role of counteranions in templating the network architecture

(6) Ability of these complexes to exchange anions

(7) Structural reorganization upon exchange of anions

(8) The guest exchange reactions of the open networks

Results and Discussion

Reactions in the Absence of Aromatic Guest. The reactions were performed by taking the ethanolic solution of ligand (1 or 2) and Cu(II) salts of ClO4, PF6, and NO3 in a 2:1 molar ratio. The reaction of 1a with Cu(ClO4)2 has been shown previously to form two types of crystals in the same reaction flask. A similar reaction but using a layering technique in the presence of CHCl3 resulted in the complex 3 containing 1D structure that is different from the previously reported structures in several ways. Further, the reactions of 1a with Cu(PF6)2 and Cu(NO3)2 resulted in fine powders (not characterized), whereas the reaction of 1b with Cu(ClO4)2 and Cu(PF6)2 resulted in crystalline complexes of 7 and 11, respectively. The reactions of 2a with all three metal salts formed neither powders nor crystals and components remained in solution, whereas the reactions of 2b with Cu(PF6)2 or Cu(ClO4)2 or Cu(NO3)2 resulted in crystalline complexes of 8 or 9 or 10, respectively.

Reactions in the Presence of Aromatics. The presence of guest molecules influenced some of the above reactions to give some interesting results. For example, the reaction of 1a with Cu(PF6)2 in the presence nitrobenzene resulted in complex 5, but surprisingly no inclusion of guest molecule was observed. As reported, the above similar reaction without nitrobenzene resulted in powders. In contrast, the presence of nitrobenzene in the reaction of 1b with Cu(PF6)2 did not show any effect and formed crystals of complex 11, whereas a similar reaction of 1b with Cu(ClO4)2 resulted in complex 6 which contains nitrobenzene as guest and with Cu(NO3)2 formed polycrystalline material which is not suitable for single-crystal analysis. The reaction of 2a with Cu(ClO4)2 resulted in crystals of complex 4 in the presence of several aromatic guest molecules. The reactions of 2b with Cu(II) salts have shown no influence of the presence of aromatic guest molecules and resulted in the same complexes 8−10. The complexes 12 and 13 were obtained from 4 and 9, respectively, by exchange of anions that otherwise cannot be synthesized by direct reactions. We have communicated our preliminary results on 6, 7, and 11 recently.

The crystal structures of complexes 3−13 were determined and analyzed in terms of coordination network geometries, recognition of networks through amide hydrogen bonds, and effects of anions and guest molecules. In all cases except 3, the equatorial positions are occupied by pyridyl groups, and the axial positions are occupied by water molecules. The coordination networks observed here include open 1D chains containing cavities (3 and 4) and open (4,4)-networks that have three types of packing modes (mixed (5), offset−offset (6 and 8), and trigonal (7)), doubly interpenetrated (4,4)-networks in parallel (9 and 10), and perpendicular (diagonal/diagonal) modes (11). The pertinent crystallographic details, bond lengths around Cu(II), and geometrical parameters of strong hydrogen bonds involving amides were given in Tables −3,respectively.

One-Dimensional Networks with Guest Inclusion. The formation of 1D networks (3 and 4) with guest inclusion were observed for the reactions of 1a and 2a with Cu(ClO4)2 in the presence of guest molecules. Although both 3 and 4 contain 1D chains, some important structural differences exist as follows. In both complexes, Cu(II) has octahedral coordination, and pyridyl groups occupy the equatorial positions. In 3, the epical positions are occupied by ClO4 - anions, while in 4 they are occupied by H2O molecules (Figures a and a). This difference can be attributed to the environments in which they are crystallized:  3 was crystallized in the presence of CHCl3 and few drops of EtOH (hydrophobic) by a layering technique, whereas 4 was crystallized in the presence of H2O, EtOH, and a few equivalents aromatic guests (hydrophilic).

This difference can be attributed to the environments in which they are crystallized: 3 was crystallized in the presence of CHCl3 and few drops of EtOH (hydrophobic) by a layering technique, whereas 4 was crystallized in the presence of H2O, EtOH, and a few equivalents aromatic guests (hydrophilic).

elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of3:  (a) 1D chain with the inclusion of CHCl3 molecules (space-fill) in rhomboidal cavities; (b) interaction of ClO4 anions with CHCl3 dimers via C−H···O interactions; (c) packing of the chains via C−H···O hydrogen bonds between ClO4 - and pyridyl C−H groups; (d) interdigitation of the chains via β-sheet hydrogen bonds; (e) β-sheet hydrogen bonds between the chains.

elements.content: The 1D chain in complex 3 has rhomboidal cavities of dimensions 13.0 × 12.3 Å, whereas in 4 it has rectangular cavities of dimensions 10.0 × 13.8 Å. The ethyl spacers of the ligands 1a and 2a exhibit gauche conformation, and both the amide moieties of the ligand are anti to each other in 3 while they are syn in 4.

elements.content: The rhomboidal cavities in 3 are occupied by CHCl3 dimers, which are held together by Cl···Cl interactions (3.641 Å, 3.920 Å, Figure b). These dimers occupy the cavities such that C−Cl moieties lie in the cavities, while C−H groups point out of the cavities (Figure c). The C−H groups of these dimers are further bonded to coordinated ClO4 - anions via C−H···O hydrogen bonds (2.600 Å, 3.445 Å, 144.43°). These chains form a layer via C−H···O hydrogen bonds between pyridyl C−H groups and ClO4 - anions (2.646 Å, 3.383 Å, 136.60°, Figure c). The 2D layers pack via interdigitation, which occurs via synthon I (β-sheet, Figure e). Further, this type of packing results in two types of channels, one of which is occupied by CHCl3, and the other is occupied by EtOH molecules (Figure d). It is found that these cavities in the 1D chain are suitable only for CHCl3, as the reactions with other guests failed to produce crystalline materials. Here it is important to note that the previously reported 1D structure of 1a with Cu(ClO4)2 contains neither guest inclusion nor synthon I.

elements.content: The cavities in 4a are occupied by naphthalene guest molecules (Figure a) that are sandwiched between four amide moieties of the ligands via π−π interactions. Besides, amide groups are also involved in extensive hydrogen bonding (not amide-to-amide) with the water molecules and the ClO4 - anions. Accordingly, 1D chains are joined together by ClO4 - anions by forming the hydrogen bonds with amide and coordinated H2O (Figure c). These layers pack with perfect overlap on each other such that the rhomboidal cavities are converted into channels (Figure d). Along these channels, the edges of naphthalene molecules interact with each other via π−π interactions (Figure b). These layers are glued together by O−H···O hydrogen bonds between the CO of 2a and coordinated and uncoordinated H2O molecules (Figure d). The guest occupied volume of 4 (22%) is much less than that of 3 (22% CHCl3 + 19% EtOH).

elements.content: Unlike in 3, the cavities in 4 are good enough to accommodate several other aromatic guest molecules such as toluene, xylene, anisole, nitrobenzene, and ethylbenzene. However, full structural analysis has been carried out only for one more complex (4b) where the toluene acts as a guest. This structure confirms that disordered toluene occupies the cavities in the 1D chain similar to the naphthalene in 4a. The cell parameters were determined for the other complexes with the above-mentioned guest molecules and it was found that they also have unit cell parameters similar to those of 4a and 4b. Here, it is interesting to note that using 2a and Zn(ClO4)2 a similar 1D chain that contains a smaller guest molecule such as CH3CN in cavities was reported earlier.

elements.content: Open Two-Dimensional Networks. Complexes 5−8 were found to contain open 2D networks of (4,4)-topology with or without inclusion of guest molecules. In 5, the layers are built up using two ligands of 1a which have different geometries. In both the ligands, the alkyl chains exhibit anti geometry and join the metal atoms with approximately equal distances (17.5 and 17.6 Å). However, the interplanar angles between amides and pyridyl planes of both ligands differ significantly. For example, in one ligand the angle between amide planes is 154.8°, whereas in the other it is 74.5°. The layers built entirely on the translational symmetry. The cavities are rhomboidal with the dimensions 19.3 × 29.3 Å (Figure a). The packing of these layers is governed by inversion symmetry and has unusual characteristics. The layers have two different interlayer interactions (Figure b). One side of the layer interacts with the neighboring layer with hydrogen bonds between amides and amide CO and coordinated H2O molecules, whereas the other side of the layer interacts with the neighboring layer by hydrogen bonds only between amide CO and coordinated H2O molecules. As a result, the interlayer separations between the layers are also different (4.6 and 4.9 Å). This type of packing generates channels in which one of the two PF6 - ions (which is not located) are accommodated (Figure c). The ligand 1a with Cu(II) was shown earlier to form two types of crystals in the same reaction flask when the anion is ClO4 -. Neither of these two complexes contains the features that are observed here. One complex exhibits a triple interpenetrated (4,4)-network, whereas the other exhibits 1D chain containing cavities. These 1D chains have features similar to those of 3 and 4, but the cavities are occupied by ClO4 - anions and the packing is constituted by N−H···O hydrogen bonds but not by the β-sheet. These observations reveal the importance of anions and the presence of guest molecules in the modulation of network geometries.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 6 contains one ligand, Cu(II) with 0.5 occupancy, 1.5 equiv of nitrobenzene, and two water molecules each having 0.5 occupancy. The butyl chains do not adopt all anti geometry but adopt gauche−anti−gauche geometry, and the ligand is partially disordered which is modeled. The Cu(II) centers are joined by the ligand with a distance of 18 Å. The (4,4)-network has rhomboidal cavities with the short axis of 18.6 Å and long axis of 30.8 Å (Figure a). The layers pack on each other via β-sheet hydrogen bonds in an offset−offset fashion with an interlayer distance of 4.45 Å (Figure b,c). The water molecules on Cu(II) form hydrogen bonds with the ClO4 - anions (O−H···O:  2.93(1) Å; 2.97(1) Å; 2.93(3) Å; 2.90(2) Å). The packing of the layers generates two types of continuous channels big and small that are occupied by nitrobenzene molecules (36% of the unit cell volume) and ClO4 - anions, respectively.

elements.content: In the case of 7, unlike in 6, the (4,4)-network is constituted by two crystallographic independent ligands that have differences in geometry of the butyl groups:  one has gauche−anti−gauche conformation. and the other has all gauche conformation. Interestingly, only one of the four amide groups in the structure engages in amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. The N−H groups of remaining three amides do not form hydrogen bonds with CO of amides:  two forms hydrogen bonds with the ClO4 - anions, and one forms a hydrogen bond with the H2O molecule. The layers have rhomboidal cavities, similar to 5 and 6, with long and short axis lengths of 31 and 18 Å, respectively, and pack in a trigonal fashion along the z-axis, crystallized in the P31 space group, such that there is continuous channel formation (Figure a,b). The channels are occupied by water and EtOH molecules, which are accounted for the 28% of the crystal volume. Each layer repeats for every three layers with an interlayer repeat distance of 4.4 Å. Further, each loop of (4,4)-nets are connected to that of the neighboring layer by six hydrogen bonds (Figure c). Two are formed between amide groups, and four are formed between Cu−OH2 and CO of the amide.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 8 is constituted by half of the ligand 2b, Cu(II) with 0.25 occupancy, PF6 - ions with half occupancy, and 1.5 equiv of H2O. The butyl chain is in disorder, and the conformation does not fall into conventional anti, gauche, and syn nomenclature as torsion angles of alkyl chains are 26.6°, 121.6°, and 26.6°. The ligand bridges the metal centers with a distance of 14.7 Å, which is much less than its 4-pyridyl analogue in 6 and 7 (17.5 Å). The (4,4)-network contains elliptical cavities with long and short axis lengths of 22.0 × 19.6 Å, respectively (Figure a). The major difference here from the above structures is the presence of 3-pyridyl instead of 4-pyridyl. As a result, the plane of the CuN4 is perpendicular to the layer, coordinated H2O molecules point into the cavities, and the layers are highly corrugated. The geometry of the layers has similar features to those of the bilayer architectures (different topology), which are formed by the T-shape coordination geometry of the metal atoms.

elements.content: These layers pack on each other via β-sheet hydrogen bonds in an offset−offset fashion with an interlayer separation of 5.1 Å (Figure b,c). Indeed, these layers interdigitate with each other similar to the bilayers (Figure d). PF6 - exists in the cavities and binds to coordinated H2O molecules via O−H···F hydrogen bonds (Figure e). For this reason, the guest molecules are not included, although the reaction was carried out in the presence of excess nitrobenzene. The size of PF6 - anions itself may be good enough to prevent the interpenetration of the networks.

elements.content: Parallel 2-Fold Interpenetration of (4,4)-Networks via β-Sheet. Complexes 9 and 10 are isostructural in the sense that both crystallized in the C2 space group and have similar cell parameters. However, the compositions of 9 and 10 differ as they contain ClO4 - and NO3 - anions, respectively. Complex 10 contains one additional water molecule to compensate for the small size of the NO3 - anion compared to the ClO4 - anion. Otherwise, both contain (4,4)-layers that are corrugated (Figure a). The butyl chains of the ligand in 9 adopt eclipsed−anti−eclipsed conformation, whereas in 10, the chains have gauche−anti−gauche conformation. The conformational differences of these ligands resulted in the differences in cavity sizes. The ligand in 9 and 10 bridges the metal atoms with distances of 14.8 and 14.6 Å, respectively. The cavities in both 9 and 10 have a rhomboidal shape with the diagonal-to-diagonal distances of 18.7 × 22.9 Å and 18.6 × 22.5 Å, respectively.

elements.content: Similar to complex 8, in both of these complexes the CuN4 plane is perpendicular to the layer, the coordinated H2O molecules point into the cavities, and the layers are highly corrugated. In both complexes, the anions occupy the cavities and form hydrogen bonds with coordinated water molecules. These layers are doubly interpenetrated in a parallel mode (Figure b). The ligands within the interpenetrated layers interact with each other via β-sheet hydrogen bonds (Figure c). The interpenetrated layers are packed via hydrogen-bonded interactions between the anions and the N−H groups of the layers (Figure d).

elements.content: Perpendicular 2-Fold Interpenetration of (4,4) Networks. The complex 11 crystallizes in acentric space group I4̄ and has features different from all the above structures, although this complex is also composed of (4,4)-layers that are similar to those of the above complexes (Figure a). In the asymmetric unit, Cu(II) is present with 0.50 occupancy, but only two PF6 - anions, each with 0.25 occupancy, are located. The major difference between this complex and the above complexes is that the (4,4)-layers are not open but doubly interpenetrated in perpendicular mode in diagonal/diagonal fashion, where in the interpenetrated layers, the Cu(II) centers of one layer are within the cavity of the other layer (Figure b). This structure has striking similarity with that of {Zn(4,4‘-bipyridine)2(H2O)(SiF6)} n , as both are doubly interpenetrated in perpendicular fashion and the channels are occupied by the counteranions. However, there is a difference between the present structure and that of Zn(II)-4,4‘-bipyridine. The present structure is crystallized in acentric space group I4̄, whereas Zn(II)-4,4‘-bipyridine is crystallized in centric space group P4/ncc. Only one of the two amide groups is engaged in amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds to join the interpenetrated layers together. The second N−H group points into the channels and may form a hydrogen bond with PF6 - ions, which we failed to locate (Figure c). The interpenetrated layers are joined further via O−H···O hydrogen bond between Cu−OH2 and CO of amide (O−H···O 2.811(5) Å).

elements.content: Transformations from 1D to Double Interpenetrated 3D-Network by Anion Exchange and Not V ice Versa . The exchange of ClO4 - anions in complex 4 with PF6 - anions resulted in the crystals of a new complex 12. The crystal structure of 12 reveals the formation of a 3D network containing rather unusual geometry. The asymmetric unit of 12 consists of two ligands of 2a, two coordinated and one free water molecules and two PF6 - anions. The two ligands have differences in conformation. The ethyl moiety adopts anti conformation in one of the ligand, whereas in the other it adopts gauche conformation. As a result, the Cu(II) centers are bridged by ligands with two distances of 10.6 and 14.5 Å. Although the metal center has square planar coordination with respect to pyridyl groups, the coordination of the ligands to Cu(II) is such that the geometry of building block can be likened to a distorted tetrahedron (Figure a). A similar type of geometry for building blocks in complexes 9 and 10 resulted in corrugated layers, which are interpenetrated in parallel mode. Although several possible network geometries exist for tetrahedral nodes, the majority of them form diamondoid networks. The geometry of the network observed here can be classified as pseudo-diamondoid or 658 (Figure b, Scheme ). The present structure constitutes the third example of such variety; the first two examples were reported by Zaworotko et al. and Cao et al., respectively. However, both those networks are neutral as they are propagated by anions. The one observed here is the first reported cationic network containing 658 geometry. Further, those two examples contain triple interpenetration, whereas the one observed here contains double interpenetration (Figure c). Despite double interpenetration, the structure contains channels that are occupied by PF6 - (Figure d). The PF6 - anions form helical chains via O−H···F hydrogen bonds with loosely coordinated water molecules (Figure e). The channel walls are composed of N−H···O, O−H···O, and C−H···O hydrogen bonds between amides, free H2O molecule, and aromatic C−H groups (Figure f).

A similar type of geometry for building blocks in complexes 9 and 10 resulted in corrugated layers, which are interpenetrated in parallel mode. Although several possible network geometries exist for tetrahedral nodes, the majority of them form diamondoid networks. The geometry of the network observed here can be classified as pseudo-diamondoid or 658 (Figure b, Scheme ). The present structure constitutes the third example of such variety; the first two examples were reported by Zaworotko et al. and Cao et al., respectively. However, both those networks are neutral as they are propagated by anions. The one observed here is the first reported cationic network containing 658 geometry. Further, those two examples contain triple interpenetration, whereas the one observed here contains double interpenetration (Figure c). Despite double interpenetration, the structure contains channels that are occupied by PF6 - (Figure d). The PF6 - anions form helical chains via O-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonds with loosely coordinated water molecules (Figure e). The channel walls are composed of N-H⋅⋅⋅O, O-H⋅⋅⋅O, and C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between amides, free H2O molecule, and aromatic C-H groups (Figure f).

elements.content: Transformations from Open Networks to Interpenetrated Networks and Not Vice Versa. The exchange of ClO4 - anions in complexes 6 and 7 with PF6 - anions results in complex 11 in good yield compared to the direct reaction. This shows that complex 11 can be synthesized in both ways. However, the reverse exchange of PF6 - anions in 11 with ClO4 - anions was found to be unsuccessful, resulting in neither powders nor crystals and the materials remain in mother liquor (Scheme ). The exchange of PF6 - anions in 8 with ClO4 - anions results in complex 9, which also was synthesized by direct reaction. The exchange of ClO4 - anions in 9 with PF6 - resulted in partial exchange of ClO4 - anions and forms complex 13 that contains PF6 - and ClO4 -, one each per Cu(II) (Scheme ).

elements.content: Exchange of Guest Molecule. Exchange (Solid-to-Solid) of Nitrobenzene in Complex 6 with Other Aromatics. When the crystals of complex 6 are placed in the solutions of anisole, p-xylene, benzonitrile, or chlorobenzene, crystals were broken into pieces, and thereby the degree of the crystalline nature decreased. The examination of IR spectra, elemental analyses, and powder spectra of these materials reveals that the exchange of guest molecules occurred with small changes in the powder patterns in the case of anisole and p-xylene (Figure a). The absence of nitrobenzene N−O stretching bands (1346 and 1527 cm-1) in IR spectra of guest exchanged materials with anisole or p-xylene confirms the complete exchange of nitrobenzene (Figure b), whereas this band is found to be present in the materials that are placed in benzonitrile or chlorobenzene, indicating that the exchange has not occurred. Further, the IR of the material that is placed in benzonitrile does not contain a C⋮N characteristic band at 2229 cm-1. The elemental analysis shows that three molecules of nitrobenzene in complex 6 are replaced by two molecules of anisole or one and half molecules of p-xylene. These results suggest that complex 6 shows some selectivity in guest exchange reactions.

elements.content: Guest Exchange with Transformation. When the crystals of the complex 6 are placed in EtOH similar to above the degree of crystalline nature decreased. The IR and powder spectra indicate the solid-to-solid transformations from complex 6 to complex 7 (Figure ). The IR spectra of complexes 6 and 7 are almost similar except that the complex 6 has an extra band at 1346 cm-1, which corresponds to the N−O stretch of nitrobenzene. The IR of 6 after placing the sample in ethanol does not contain this band. Moreover, the powder patterns of complexes 6 and 7 have significant differences, which confirms the fact that indeed transformations from 6 to 7 occurred in solid-to-solid fashion (Scheme ).

elements.content: Influence of Anions on Network Geometries. The anions considered in these studies include NO3 -, ClO4 -, and PF6 -. These three anions have shown different abilities in the formation of crystalline complexes and also in templating network geometries. In direct reactions under identical conditions, ClO4 - anions have shown more capability in the formation of several crystalline complexes with 1 or 2 and Cu(II), whereas PF6 - anions have shown moderate ability and NO3 - anions have shown very poor ability in producing crystalline complexes of ligand 1 or 2 and Cu(II). The differences in the shape, size, and hydrogen-bonding ability of the anions have influenced the structural features of the MOFs. To look at the effect of anions, it is advisable to analyze the reactions that are performed under identical conditions except for a change in anions. Here, we have three such reactions that are performed under identical conditions and obtained the crystalline products. For example, reaction of 1b with Cu(II) under identical conditions but with PF6 - and ClO4 - resulted in different structures, 6 and 7 ((4,4)-open networks) with ClO4 - anions and 11 (perpendicularly interpenetrated) with PF6 - anions. The shape of the channels in 11 indicates that the formation of this network is influenced by the shape of PF6 -. Similarly, 2b with Cu(PF6)2 and Cu(ClO4)2 or Cu(NO3)2 under identical conditions resulted in complexes 8 and 9 or 10, respectively. In contrast to previous examples here the PF6 - anions templated an open network, whereas ClO4 - anions templated an interpenetrated (parallel) network. However, structures 9 and 10 are identical, indicating that the differences between NO3 - and ClO4 - are negligible. All these examples indicate that there is considerable difference between PF6 - and ClO4 - in the templation of the networks. We note here that the β-sheet formation occurred more frequently in the presence of ClO4 - (3 out of 5) than PF6 - (1 out of 4). Therefore, the interference of PF6 - anions in amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds is more than that of ClO4 -. This may be well understood given the fact that the N−H···F hydrogen bond is stronger than the N−H···O hydrogen bond. These studies show that the effect of ions is the combination of their size as well as their electronic effects.

elements.content: Amide-to-Amide Hydrogen Bonds. Our previous studies on crystal structures of analogues of 1 and 2 show that the amide-to-amide hydrogen bond occurs only when the angle between pyridyl and amide groups is above 20°. To see a similar correlation in coordination networks, we have calculated these angles for all these structures reported here. It is interesting to note that all the structures contain amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds, except 4, although there is a strong competition of acceptors in the form of anions. The β-sheet hydrogen-bond formation has been observed in complexes 3, 6, 9, 10, and 13; complex 8 forms a rarely observed α-sheet. In these complexes, except 3 (5°), all the interplanar angles between the pyridyl and amide planes are found to be above 20° (24° and 27° in 6, 39° in 8, 39° and 22° in 9, and 33° and 23° in 10), and hence the formation of synthon I (β-sheet) and III (α-sheet) occurred. In complex 11, although the ligand has interplanar angles above 20° (28° and 26°), only one of the amide involves in amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds, whereas the other involves in N−H···F interactions with the anion. The complexes 5, 7, and 12 have two molecules in asymmetric unit and have the interplanar angles of 17.5° & 26.7° and 2.5° & 21.8° in 5, 38.6° & 23° and 19.9° & 25.8° in 7, and 37.9° & 17.1° and 27.8° & 36.2° in 12. These observations suggest that the presence of the angle requirement is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for the amide-to-amide hydrogen-bond formation. The only exception was found in complex 3, which forms a β-sheet despite the lower angle (4°). This could be attributed due to the arclike geometry of the molecule unlike those in other structures.

elements.content: Ligands 1 and 2 with Cu(II) were shown to form coordination networks with versatile topologies. The network geometries include 1D chains containing guest molecules in cavities, 2D open (4,4) networks containing solvents/anions in the cavities, doubly interpenetrated (4,4)-networks in parallel and perpendicular fashion, and a 3D pseudo-diamondoid network. These coordination networks were found to assemble each other via N−H···O hydrogen-bond synthons I−III. The exchange of anions resulted in the new crystalline complexes, which are otherwise not possible to synthesize via direct reactions. For example, the exchange of ClO4 - anions with PF6 - anions from complex 4 was shown to form an unusual 3D pseudo-diamondoid network (12), which we failed to synthesize by direct reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Ligands 1 and 2 with Cu(II) were shown to form coordination networks with versatile topologies. The network geometries include 1D chains containing guest molecules in cavities, 2D open (4,4) networks containing solvents/anions in the cavities, doubly interpenetrated (4,4)-networks in parallel and perpendicular fashion, and a 3D pseudo-diamondoid network. These coordination networks were found to assemble each other via N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bond synthons I-III. The exchange of anions resulted in the new crystalline complexes, which are otherwise not possible to synthesize via direct reactions. For example, the exchange of ClO4 - anions with PF6 - anions from complex 4 was shown to form an unusual 3D pseudo-diamondoid network (12), which we failed to synthesize by direct reaction.

elements.content: These results clearly indicate that the transformations from open-to-interpenetrated can be triggered by an exchange of anions, but transformations from interpenetrated to an open variety are not allowed. They further demonstrate the fact that the formation of an end product will be determined by the structure of the starting materials. The dissolution of these complexes in a solvent is not the same as the dissolution of individual components in the solvent. The memory of the supramolecular information of the starting material may influence the structure of the final product.

elements.content: The use of 3-pyridyl in place of 4-pyridyl was found to affect the geometry of the networks. For example, the ligand 2b, which has a 3-pyridyl group, has always resulted in the formation of 2D corrugated networks with coordinated water molecules pointing inside the cavities. In these structures, the cavities are always occupied by anions due to hydrogen-bonded interactions between the anions and coordinated water molecules. As a result, no inclusion of guest molecules was observed in the complexes of 2 with the exception of complex 4.

Therefore, the cavities in these structures were occupied by the guest molecules. The complex 6 has shown selectivity toward the guest exchange reactions. Guest-induced transformation of 6 to 7 was observed.

elements.content: General. Fourier transform IR (FTIR) spectra were recorded with an NEXUS-870 instrument, Thermo Nicolet Corporation. Elemental analyses were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer instrument, series II, CHNS/O analyzer 2400. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer instrument, Pyris Diamond TG/DTA (air). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded with a Philips PW 1710 diffractometer. The ligands were prepared according to procedures previously reported by us. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General. Fourier transform IR (FTIR) spectra were recorded with an NEXUS-870 instrument, Thermo Nicolet Corporation. Elemental analyses were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer instrument, series II, CHNS/O analyzer 2400. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer instrument, Pyris Diamond TG/DTA (air). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded with a Philips PW 1710 diffractometer. The ligands were prepared according to procedures previously reported by us. Complex 3 was prepared by the layering technique, 4-11 were prepared by direct reaction, and 12 and 13 were prepared by anion exchange reactions.

elements.content: Synthesis of Complex 3 by Layering. The ligand 1a (54.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was taken in CHCl3−EtOH (10:1) solvent (5.5 mL). An ethanolic solution (1.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (37.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was slowly layered over the ligand solution. The slow diffusion of the components resulted in the formation of purple-colored crystals after one week. Yield:  72.3 mg (61.1% yield); elemental analysis:  C38H42Cl8Cu1N8O14 (1181.94):  Calculated:  C 38.58%, H 3.55%, N 9.47%; Found:  C 38.46%, H 3.51%, N 9.39%; IR (cm-1):  3436 (O−H stretch), 3289 (N−H stretch), 3085 (aromatic C−H stretch), 1639 (amide CO stretch), 1548 (amide II), 1088 (ClO4).
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of Complex 3 by Layering. The ligand 1a (54.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was taken in CHCl3-EtOH (10:1) solvent (5.5 mL). An ethanolic solution (1.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (37.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was slowly layered over the ligand solution. The slow diffusion of the components resulted in the formation of purple-colored crystals after one week. Yield: 72.3 mg (61.1% yield); elemental analysis: C38H42Cl8Cu1N8O14 (1181.94): Calculated: C 38.58%, H 3.55%, N 9.47%; Found: C 38.46%, H 3.51%, N 9.39%; IR (cm-1): 3436 (O-H stretch), 3289 (N-H stretch), 3085 (aromatic C-H stretch), 1639 (amide CO stretch), 1548 (amide II), 1088 (ClO4).

elements.content: Synthesis of Complex 4 − 11 by Direct Reactions. The complexes 4−11 were prepared by the direct mixing of ligand with metal, and the precipitate resulting during the reaction was dissolved by adding water. The following two procedures were adopted for synthesizing them:  one without guest (7−11) and other in the presence of guest (4−6, 8−11).
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of Complex 4 - 11 by Direct Reactions. The complexes 4-11 were prepared by the direct mixing of ligand with metal, and the precipitate resulting during the reaction was dissolved by adding  water. The following two procedures were adopted for synthesizing them: one without guest (7-11) and other in the presence of guest (4-6, 8-11).

elements.content: Complex Preparations without Guest. Complex 7 was prepared by dissolving 1b (596.0 mg, 2.0 mmol) in 30.0 mL of EtOH. To the above solution, addition of ethanolic solution (10.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (370.1 mg, 1.0 mmol) resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15−20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added to the solution. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after 8−10 days. Complexes 8−11 were also prepared in a similar way by taking the corresponding ligands and Cu(II) salts. The reaction with Cu(PF6)2 were performed by taking perchlorate or nitrate salts of Cu(II) and NH4PF6 in a 1:4 ratio.

elements.content: Complex Preparations with Guest. Complex 4:  ethanolic solution (20 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (370.15 mg, 1.0 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of ligand 2a (540 mg, 2.0 mmol) and naphthalene (2.56 g, 20 mmol) in 30 mL of EtOH. This resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15−20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after one week. In the case of solid guest molecules, 20 equiv of guest was used for 1 equiv of metal salt, whereas for liquid aromatic guest molecules, 20 mL of the solvent was used. Complexes 5, 6, and 8−11 were prepared in a similar way by using the corresponding ligands, Cu(II) salts, and guest molecules.

This resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15-20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after one week. In the case of solid guest molecules, 20 equiv of guest was used for 1 equiv of metal salt, whereas for liquid aromatic guest molecules, 20 mL of the solvent was used. Complexes 5, 6, and 8-11 were prepared in a similar way by using the corresponding ligands, Cu(II) salts, and guest molecules.

elements.content:
Conversion of 6 to 7:  IR (cm-1):  3357 (N−H stretch) 3089 (aromatic C−H stretch), 1648 (amide CO), 1551 (amide II).

X-ray Crystallography. The single-crystal data was collected on a Bruker-Nonius Mach3 CAD4 X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (μ = 0.71073 Å) by the ω-scan method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-square methods on F 2 using SHELX-97. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The EtOH molecules in 3, one of the PF6 ions in 5 and 11 could not be located. These structures are refined using platon squeeze option. The disorder of toluene in 4b, nitrobenzene, and ligand in 6 and butyl chains of the ligands in 8 and 13 was modeled and refined (Scheme ). In complex 7, the presence of one EtOH and one water molecule per Cu(II) was evidenced by elemental and TGA analysis. However, in X-ray analysis the O-atoms of water and ethanol were located and refined but failed to locate carbon atoms of the EtOH.

Synthesis of Complex 3 by Layering. The ligand 1a (54.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was taken in CHCl3−EtOH (10:1) solvent (5.5 mL). An ethanolic solution (1.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (37.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was slowly layered over the ligand solution. The slow diffusion of the components resulted in the formation of purple-colored crystals after one week. Yield:  72.3 mg (61.1% yield); elemental analysis:  C38H42Cl8Cu1N8O14 (1181.94):  Calculated:  C 38.58%, H 3.55%, N 9.47%; Found:  C 38.46%, H 3.51%, N 9.39%; IR (cm-1):  3436 (O−H stretch), 3289 (N−H stretch), 3085 (aromatic C−H stretch), 1639 (amide CO stretch), 1548 (amide II), 1088 (ClO4).

Complex Preparations without Guest. Complex 7 was prepared by dissolving 1b (596.0 mg, 2.0 mmol) in 30.0 mL of EtOH. To the above solution, addition of ethanolic solution (10.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (370.1 mg, 1.0 mmol) resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15−20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added to the solution. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after 8−10 days. Complexes 8−11 were also prepared in a similar way by taking the corresponding ligands and Cu(II) salts. The reaction with Cu(PF6)2 were performed by taking perchlorate or nitrate salts of Cu(II) and NH4PF6 in a 1:4 ratio.

Complex Preparations with Guest. Complex 4:  ethanolic solution (20 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (370.15 mg, 1.0 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of ligand 2a (540 mg, 2.0 mmol) and naphthalene (2.56 g, 20 mmol) in 30 mL of EtOH. This resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15−20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after one week. In the case of solid guest molecules, 20 equiv of guest was used for 1 equiv of metal salt, whereas for liquid aromatic guest molecules, 20 mL of the solvent was used. Complexes 5, 6, and 8−11 were prepared in a similar way by using the corresponding ligands, Cu(II) salts, and guest molecules.

Synthesis of Complex 3 by Layering. The ligand 1a (54.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was taken in CHCl3-EtOH (10:1) solvent (5.5 mL). An ethanolic solution (1.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (37.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was slowly layered over the ligand solution. The slow diffusion of the components resulted in the formation of purple-colored crystals after one week. Yield: 72.3 mg (61.1% yield); elemental analysis: C38H42Cl8Cu1N8O14 (1181.94): Calculated: C 38.58%, H 3.55%, N 9.47%; Found: C 38.46%, H 3.51%, N 9.39%; IR (cm-1): 3436 (O-H stretch), 3289 (N-H stretch), 3085 (aromatic C-H stretch), 1639 (amide CO stretch), 1548 (amide II), 1088 (ClO4). 

 Complex Preparations without Guest. Complex 7 was prepared by dissolving 1b (596.0 mg, 2.0 mmol) in 30.0 mL of EtOH. To the above solution, addition of ethanolic solution (10.0 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (370.1 mg, 1.0 mmol) resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15-20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added to the solution. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after 8-10 days. Complexes 8-11 were also prepared in a similar way by taking the corresponding ligands and Cu(II) salts. The reaction with Cu(PF6)2 were performed by taking perchlorate or nitrate salts of Cu(II) and NH4PF6 in a 1:4 ratio. 

 Complex Preparations with Guest. Complex 4: ethanolic solution (20 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (370.15 mg, 1.0 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of ligand 2a (540 mg, 2.0 mmol) and naphthalene (2.56 g, 20 mmol) in 30 mL of EtOH. This resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 15-20 min of stirring, 20 mL of water was added. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue-colored crystals were formed after one week. In the case of solid guest molecules, 20 equiv of guest was used for 1 equiv of metal salt, whereas for liquid aromatic guest molecules, 20 mL of the solvent was used. Complexes 5, 6, and 8-11 were prepared in a similar way by using the corresponding ligands, Cu(II) salts, and guest molecules.
